relation.name: Circumstance
relation.satellite: A (non-hypothetical) state of affairs.
relation.nucsat: S sets a framework in the subject matter within which R is intended to interpret N.
relation.effect: R recognizes that S provides the framework for interpreting N.
relation.connectives: when; while; ...; wenn; waehrend; ... for temporal circum- stantials
relation.example: [Als die Veag wegen der Liberalisierung des Strommarktes unter Druck geriet,]S [hielt sie sich bei ihren Lieferanten schadlos.]N (maz-5297)

relation.name: Condition
relation.satellite: A hypothetical, future, or otherwise unrealized situation (relative to the situational context of S).
relation.nucsat: Realization of N depends on realization of S.
relation.effect: R recognizes how the realization of N depends on the realization of S.

relation.name: Otherwise
relation.nucleus: A hypothetical, future or in some other way unrealized state of affairs.
relation.satellite: A hypothetical, future or in some other way unrealized state of affairs.
relation.nucsat: The realization of N prevents realization of S.
relation.effect: R recognizes the dependency relation of prevention between the realization of N and the realization of S.

relation.name: Unless
relation.nucleus: A hypothetical, future or in some other way unrealized state of affairs.
relation.satellite: A hypothetical, future or in some other way unrealized state of affairs.
relation.nucsat: S affects the realization of N; N is realized provided that S is not realized.
relation.effect: R recognizes that N is realized provided that S is not realized.
relation.example: [Morgen wird der Satellit in den Pazifik stuerzen.]N [Es sei denn, er verglueht doch noch vollstaendig in der Erdatmosphaere.]S

relation.name: Elaboration
relation.nucsat: S presents additional detail about the situation (not about an individual entity – cf. E-Elaboration below) that is presented in N or inferentially accessible in N. Some typical relations between N and S are abstraction–instance, event–subevent.
relation.effect: R recognizes S as providing additional detail for N.
relation.connectives: in particular; for example; ... / besonders; beispielsweise; ...
relation.example: [Diepensee siedelt um.]N [Ohne Wenn und Aber.]S (maz-6993)

relation.name: E-Elaboration
relation.nucsat: S presents additional detail about an entity mentioned in N. N precedes S in the text. Some typical relations between N and S are set–member and whole–part.
relation.effect: R recognizes S as providing additional detail about an entity mentioned in N.
relation.example: [Heute wollen Tausende das Flair eines historischen Klassenzimmers kennen lernen,]N [wie sie nur noch wenige in Deutschland existieren.]S (maz-6728)
relation.comment: In the example, the wie minor clause (S) does not relate to the whole event of acquainting but only to the class room, i.e., an entity within N. .

relation.name: Interpretation
relation.nucsat: S relates N to a framework of ideas not involved in N itself and not concerned with W’s positive regard; or at least, positive regard is not the important point. In the text, N precedes S.
relation.effect: R recognizes the interpreting function of S for N.
relation.example: [In Potsdam findet heute der große Festzug zu Ehren von Friedrich II. statt.]N [Damit sind die diesjaehrigen “Preußen-Tage” beendet.]S
relation.comment: If the main point of S is to assess N on a scale, the suitable relation is not Interpretation but Evaluation-N/Evaluation-S.

relation.name: Means
relation.nucleus: An activity.
relation.nucsat: S presents a method or instrument which tends to make realization of N more likely.
relation.effect: R recognizes that the method or instrument in S tends to make realization of N more likely.

relation.name: Cause
relation.nucleus: A state of affairs holding in the world. This state has been caused by the situation presented in S.
relation.satellite: A state of affairs holding in the world.
relation.nucsat: The state of affairs in N is being caused by the state of affairs in S.
relation.effect: R recognizes the causal relationship between the two states of affairs.
relation.example: Unerwartete Pressemeldung zur Verlegung des Ortes Diepensee. [ueberrascht reagierte auch Buergermeister Jochen Wagner.]N [Schließlich gaben die Stadtverord- neten erst Montagabend gruenes Licht fuer die weitere Erschließung des neuen Ortsteils Diepensee.]S (maz-6993)

relation.name: Result
relation.nucleus: A state of affairs holding in the world. This state provides the reason for the situation presented in S.
relation.satellite: A state of affairs holding in the world.
relation.nucsat: The state of affairs in S is being caused by the state of affairs in N.
relation.effect: R recognizes the causal relationship between the two states of affairs.
relation.comment: Dual of Cause. The choice between Cause and Result is made solely on the grounds of relative importance for the tweet.

relation.name: Purpose
relation.nucleus: An activity.
relation.satellite: A hypothetical, future or in some other way unrealized state of affairs. This state is expected to be achieved after the activity described in N is fulfilled.
relation.nucsat: S is to be realized through the activity in N.
relation.effect: R recognizes that the activity in N is initiated in order to realize S.
relation.connectives: by means of; in order to; ... / durch; um .. zu; ...
relation.example: [Um ihre Soldaten zu schuetzen,]S [aeußern sich die USA nicht zu Berichten ueber den Beginn der Boden-Operation in Afghanistan.]N (maz-5701)
relation.comment: There is, in a wide sense, a causal relation between S and N. The difference to the relations Cause/Result is that for Purpose, S is an unrealized state of affairs that is the intention of the actor.

relation.name: Solutionhood
relation.satellite: S presents a problem.
relation.nucsat: N is a solution to the problem presented in S. In the text, S usually precedes N.
relation.effect: R recognizes N as a solution to the problem presented in S
relation.example: [Mit der Verabschiedung des Nichtraucherschutzgesetzes sitzen viele Kneipen in der Falle.]S [Es empfiehlt sich, frueh genug auf die Einrichtung abtrennbarer Raeume zu achten.]N

relation.name: Contrast
relation.nucleus: No more than two nuclei; the situations in these two nuclei are (a) comprehended as the same in many respects (b) comprehended as differing in a few respects and (c) compared with respect to one or more of these differences.
relation.effect: R recognizes the comparability and the difference(s) yielded by the compar- ison is being made.
relation.connectives: on the other hand; but; while; ... / demgegenueber; hingegen; waehrend; aber; ...
relation.example: [Mein erstes Auto war ein Kleinwagen.]N [Das zweite hingegen ein aus- gewachsener Kombi.]N

relation.name: Sequence
relation.nucleus: The nuclei describe states of affairs in the world that take place in a temporal order.
relation.effect: R recognizes the temporal succession relationships among the nuclei..
relation.connectives: then; afterwards; before; ... / dann; anschließend; und; zuvor, ...
relation.example: [Um neun betrat die Lehrerin den Klassenraum.]N [Fuenf Minuten spaeter verkuendete sie, dass ein Test geschrieben wird.]N
relation.comment: The presentation of the states of affairs in the text can be in the ”real” order (dann) or in reversed order (before).

relation.name: Background
relation.nucsat: S increases the ability of R to comprehend an element in N. S contains orienting background information, in whose absence N would be hard to understand. In a tweet, S usually precedes N, but not always.
relation.effect: R’s ability to comprehend N increases.
relation.example: [Burkina Faso hieß bis 1984 noch Obervolta.]S [Nach einer EMNID- Umfrage glauben viele Europaeer bis heute, dass es sich um zwei verschiedene Laender handelt.]N

relation.name: Antithesis
relation.nucleus: W has positive regard for N.
relation.satellite: In comparison to N, W regards the content of S as less positive or less important.
relation.nucsat: N and S are in contrast (see the Contrast relation); because of the incom- patibility that arises from the contrast, one cannot have positive regard for both of those situations. One subgroup is corrections of the kind ”Not A happened, but B.” In a tweet, S usually precedes N.
relation.effect: R’s positive regard for N is increased.
relation.comment: Similar relations are Concession and multinuclear Contrast. See Section 3.6.

relation.name: Concession
relation.nucleus: W has positive regard for N.
relation.satellite: In comparison to N, W regards the content of S as less positive or less important but acknowledges its truth (in a wide sense).
relation.nucsat: W acknowledges that N and S in general are potentially incompatible; but in the current described situation, both hold.
relation.effect: R’s positive regard for N is increased
relation.connectives: although; but; nonetheless; still; ... / obwohl; trotzdem; aber; ...
relation.example: [Sanitaere Anlagen gehoeren heute zum Standard großer Liegeplaetze.]S [Doch mit der Nachruestung tut sich Radewege schwer.]N (maz-6488)

relation.name: Evidence
relation.nucleus: A subjective statetement or assessment that R might not believe to a degree satisfactory to W.
relation.satellite: A statement that R will find credible; often the description of an ‘objective fact’.
relation.nucsat: R’s comprehending S increases R’s belief of N.
relation.effect: R’s belief in N is increased.
relation.example: Streit um das Nebeneinander der Schulfaecher Religion und LER [Und nun scheint sogar unsere Landesregierung entschlossen, diese scheinbare Gleichbe- handlung der beiden Faecher zu beseitigen.]N [Stolpe, Reiche und Co. sagen zwar Ja zu einem moeglichen Kompromissangebot aus Karlsruhe, dekretieren aber: Einen Wahlpflichtbereich LER/Religion kann es nicht geben.]S (maz-6159)

relation.name: Reason
relation.nucleus: A subjective statement/thesis that R might not accept or regard as positive/important.
relation.satellite: A subjective statement/thesis.
relation.nucsat: R’s comprehending S increases R’s readiness to accept N or to share the ex- pressed opinion of W.
relation.effect: R’s belief in N is increased.
relation.example: [Die Militaerschlaege der USA verlieren mit jedem Tag weiteren Bombarde- ments schleichend an Glaubwuerdigkeit.]N [Mit flaechenhafter Zerstoerung sind weder die Taliban noch bin Laden zu treffen.]S (maz-5701)
relation.comment: Reason is more specific than Evidence: the difference is in whether W presents S as ‘objective fact’ (Evidence) or as a subjective assessment (Reason).

relation.name: Reason-N
relation.nucleus: A subjective statement/thesis.
relation.nucsat: R’s comprehending N increases R’s readiness to accept S or to share the ex- pressed opinion of W.
relation.effect: R’s belief in S is increased.

relation.name: Justify
relation.nucleus: A subjective statetement or assessment that R might not accept.
relation.satellite: A subjective statement of a general (for example moral) attitude or position of the acting person.
relation.nucsat: R’s comprehending S increases R’s readiness to accept W’s right to present N.
relation.effect: R’s inclination for accepting W’s presentation of N is increased.
relation.example: [Dieses Gericht werde ich niemals essen.]S [Ich bin Vegetarier.]N

relation.name: Evaluation-S
relation.nucleus: Description of a state of affairs, or a subjective statement (but not from the perspective of W).
relation.satellite: A subjective evaluation (positive/negative, desirable/not desirable) from W’s per- spective.
relation.nucsat: S evaluates N.
relation.effect: R recognizes the evaluation relationship between S and N.
relation.example: [Seine Vergangenheit schien wie ein Fluch b ̈er dem Hotelkomplex zu liegen.]S [Jahrelang hatte das Amtsgericht Potsdam umsonst versucht, es an den Mann zu bringen.]N (maz-6193)
relation.comment: In most cases the evaluating statement follows the one being evaluated.

relation.name: Evaluation-N
relation.nucleus: A subjective evaluation (positive/negative, desirable/not desirable) from W’s perspective.
relation.satellite: Description of a state of affairs, or a subjective statement (but not from the perspective of W).
relation.nucsat: N evaluates S
relation.effect: R recognizes the evaluation relationship between S and N.

relation.name: Motivation
relation.nucleus: An action in which R is the actor.
relation.nucsat: S provides an incentive/motivation/reason for performing the action in N.
relation.effect: R’s desire to perform action in N is increased.
relation.example: [Olympische Spiele stellen fuer jeden Austragungsort einen großen Gewinn dar.]S [Berlin muss sich jetzt um die Spiele 2016 bewerben!]N

relation.name: Enablement
relation.nucleus: An action in which R is the actor.
relation.nucsat: R comprehending S increases R’s potential ability to perform the action in N.
relation.effect: R’s potential ability to perform the action in N increases.
relation.example: [Wechseln Sie die Zuendkerzen aus.]N [Ein Vierkantschluessel befindet sich unter der Abdeckung.]S

relation.name: Attribution
relation.satellite: The satellite describes the fact that the author expresses the information which is presented in N.
relation.nucsat: S specifies the original author of information presented in N.
relation.connectives: (rarely marked by connectives; usually delimited by dash or colon)
relation.example: Friedrich gegen doppelte Staatsangeh\"origkeit: [”Waere integrationshemmend”,]N [sagt er #berlindirekt.]S

relation.name: Address
relation.satellite: The satellite contains (a list of) syntactically independent names or @-mentions that are being addressed by the given message.
relation.effect: R understands who is being addressed by the message.
relation.comment: You should link the @-mention to the highest possible level of the dis- course tree which contains information relevant for addressee.

relation.name: Hashtag
relation.satellite: The satellite contains (a list of) syntactically independent @-mention(s). These mentions show to which user the given message is addressed.
relation.effect: R can proceed to the information pointed by the URI.
relation.comment: You should link the @-mention to the highest possible level of the dis- course tree for which it still provides relevant information.

relation.name: List
relation.nucleus: The nuclei provide information that play identical roles for the tweet, in the way of an enumeration.
relation.effect: R recognizes the comparability of thenlinked items.
relation.example: Was ich gestern getan habe? [Essen kochen,]N [Kinder versorgen,]N [Bad putzen.]N

relation.name: Joint
relation.nucleus: The nuclei give different kinds of information, hence there is no List enumeration; at the same time they are not in any clearly recognizable semantic or pragmatic relation. Yet there is coherence by contributing to the overall function of the tweet.
relation.effect: R recognizes the distinct functions of the nuclei.
relation.connectives: additive connectives such as also, further / zudem, auch
relation.comment: Joint is to be used when a multinuclear relation is in order but none of the ”stronger” relations hold.

relation.name: OTHER
relation.nucleus: Any.
relation.satellite: Any.
relation.nucsat: The relationship.
relation.comment: This relation has the lowest precedence in our relation hierarchy and should only be applied when none of the existing relations seems to be appropriate.

relation.name: Preparation
relation.nucsat: S precedes N in the text; S tends to make R more ready, interested or oriented for reading N. However, S does not provide information that makes understanding the content of N easier (cf. Background).
relation.effect: R is more ready, interested or oriented for reading N.
relation.connectives: (rarely marked by connectives; sometimes by colon)
relation.example: [Denn eines ist klar:]S [Die Militaerschlaege der USA verlieren mit jedem Tag weiteren Bombardements schleichend an Glaubwuerdigkeit.]N (maz-5701)
relation.comment: This relation applies when S does not have any stronger role than setting the topic of N or playing a similarly preparatory role. Thus S must not transmit a full unit of information.

relation.name: Restatement
relation.nucsat: S restates N, where S and N are of comparable bulk; N is more central to W’s purposes than S is.
relation.effect: R recognizes S as a restatement of N.
relation.example: [Der Buergermeister hat den Stadtverordneten alle Informationen gegeben,]N [also gewissermaßen die Karten auf den Tisch gelegt.]S

relation.name: Same
relation.nucsat: Used for two parts of the same segment if they were split apart by a parenthetical construction.
relation.connectives: (rarely marked by connectives; sometimes by colon)
relation.example: [@Schaf reloaded] [da]N [wo noch O ̈l ist ,]S [riecht es noch...]N

relation.name: URI
relation.satellite: The satellite contains a URI which is not syntactically embedded in any clause but possibly links to a resource with further relevant information.
relation.effect: R can proceed to the information pointed by the URI.
relation.comment: You should link the URI to the highest possible level of the discourse tree for which it still provides relevant information.
